ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
I learned to critically analyze an art form that I've always admired but never had examined in a formal academic setting.
I also examined different forms of writing about the arts and developed my own style in essays/editorials.

I learned so much from this course. I always loved musicals, but this course taught me how to talk about them and why they work. I also learned a lot about how to listen to musical theater and understand it in context of its development over the 20th century. I also got a lot better at writing about theater and music, and got to listen to many musicals I hadn't been exposed to before.
Different methods of writing and analyzing musical theater. Learned the important landmark shows spanning the 20-21st century and their importance.
I gained a much broader understanding of the history of musical theater and its impacts on present day musical theater and the broader theater industry.
Now have a better understand of the American musical theater tradition from its conception to present day from a historical and compositional perspective
LOVE THIS COURSE. Prof takes you through this history of musical theater in such a wonderful way, from vaudeville to now.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Lectures were well-organized, always keeping class at a captivating pace. Cold-calling encouraged students to come to class prepared. We analyzed theater from a variety of perspectives (cultural, musical, technical, etc.), all of which were respected and valued. Egan paid attention to the students as individuals, keeping track of engagement and providing feedback during one-on-one meetings. The class field trip to see a Broadway show and the guest speakers enhanced my learning. 
Weaknesses: Final paper prompt was vague; I wasn't sure what the expectations were.

This course's main strength was the organization and format. I loved that we focused on a couple musicals each week in order to tackle wider themes. The only weakness is that sometimes Prof. Egan asks very clearly leading questions since he wants to steer the conversation a certain way. I otherwise really liked the way he managed seminars and I felt like my voice was heard.

Although theres a good amount of reading, the class is very engaging and can be interesting to all types of people with diverse interests. The conversations, readings, and writings were fun and thought-provoking.

I think considering the sheer amount of history, Professor Egan did a great job of organizing the most important works and time periods and giving them attention. Professor Egan is a very thoughtful professor who puts in great amounts of effort to ensure his students are not only participating and retaining information, but that are also enjoying the material and experience.
There were many strengths, such  as the attention to detail, class discussion portion and reading materials selected. More balanced syllabus, it felt like we rushed through certain shows/ era
Dan is a huge strength of the course; you can really tell that he cares about his students as well as the content itself. He created an atmosphere that I always loved coming to.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I found musical theater the perfect prism to examine social issues, which I can apply to my major coursework. For a theater enthusiast, I found this class much more intellectually challenging/stimulating than other theater classes I have taken at Yale.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone who cares about musical theater. I learned so much and also it was really fun. I am not a music or theater major but I'm passionate about musicals and that was all I needed to enjoy the class.

Definitely. Great history course under the theater major and great course in general. Also great in identifying whats wrong with the industry and how we can change it. Whether or not you think youre interested in musical theater, take this course to influence that or inspire you to take action in it.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone, specifically those interested in theater and musical theater history. It is incredibly valuable particularly for those interested in the industry currently, because everything that exists today in theater is derived from its history (especially throughout musical theater).
YES, if you get in take the class!
